frame.name: Prohibiting_or_licensing
frame.definition:
<def-root>In this frame a <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> is prohibited (or allowed) by a <fen>Principle</fen>. Raising constructions are common in this frame. Because laws and principles usually focus on what is not allowed, the words of this frame that are synonyms of prohibit.v are considered more basic, and the words that are synonyms of permit.v are marked with the semantic type "Negative".
<ex> <fex name="State_of_affairs">Guns</fex> were <t>prohibited</t> <fex name="Place">in the airport</fex> .</ex> <ex> <fex name="Principle">Code 1425</fex> <t>bans</t> <fex name="State_of_affairs">large trucks</fex> <fex name="Place">in the tunnel</fex>.</ex> <ex> <fex name="State_of_affairs">Children</fex> were not <t>permitted</t> <fex name="State_of_affairs">in the office</fex>. <fex name="Prin">CNI</fex></ex> <ex> <fex name="Principle">Code 1425</fex> <t>allows</t> <fex name="State_of_affairs">us</fex> <fex name="State_of_affairs">to deduct interest payments</fex>.</ex> <ex><fex name="Principle">No religion</fex> <t>accepts</t> <fex name="State_of_affairs">discrimination against women</fex>.</ex>
In this frame the <fen>Principle</fen> which prohibits the <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> is not an agent who denies permission to a specific individual or group of individuals, and thus differs from the Authority in the Deny_permission frame. </def-root>

FE.name: Principle
FE.definition:
<def-root>A moral, legal, or social norm which rules a <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> to be inadmissible behavior or an outcome of behavior.
<ex><fex name="Prin">The Establishment Clause of the First Amendment</fex> plainly <t>prohibits</t> the establishment of a national religion by Congress.</ex>
</def-root>

FE.name: Circumstances
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Circumstances</fen> are the conditions under which the <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> is prohibited.</def-root>

FE.name: Explanation
FE.definition: <def-root>The reason for which the <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> is prohibited. </def-root>
